title: The Hon. East India Company’s steamer Nemesis and the boats of the Sulphur, Calliope, Larne, and Starling, destroying the Chinese war junks in Anson’s Bay, January 7, 1841
content:
accession_no_csv: 2016-00300

  Image: 

  object_work_type: steel engravings (visual works) prints (visual works)

  title_text: The Hon. East India Company’s steamer Nemesis and the boats of the Sulphur
 Calliope
 Larne
 and Starling
 destroying the Chinese war junks in Anson’s Bay
 January 7
 1841

 G. (George)

  physical_appearance: This artwork depicts a naval battle. Smoke and fires can be seen emanating from a wrecked ship. The British flag is present on the large steamer
 as well as on the numerous smaller boats that are ferrying a large number of people. The print has a wooden frame serving as its perimeter. Inside its white border
 there are decorative designs near the bottom half. At the bottom left and bottom right of the print
 the names of the artist and the engraver of this print are stated respectively. The colours on the print do not look smudged. The title of the print is stated at the bottom centre.

  subject_terms_1: junks (vessels) naval battles fire damage wars steamships

  subject_terms_2: Engraving Steamboats Prints Nemesis (Steamer) East India Company China History Opium War
 1840 - 1842 Naval battles Junks

  subject_terms_3: East India Company Visual arts

  sgcool_label_text: This print depicts the attack by the Nemesis on Chinese war junks at Anson’s Bay on 7 January 1841. Known as the Second Battle of Chuenpee
 the attack was part of the First Opium War
 and contributed to the eventual cession of Hong Kong island to the British. The Nemesis
 captained by Edward Belcher
 was the first steam powered warship used in action by Britain. This print
 based on a painting by George W. Terry
 was published in Lieutenant Colonel Williams’ England’s Battles by Sea and Land by the London Printing and Publishing Company.

metadata.physical_appearance: This artwork depicts a naval battle. Smoke and fires can be seen emanating from a wrecked ship. The British flag is present on the large steamer, as well as on the numerous smaller boats that are ferrying a large number of people. The print has a wooden frame serving as its perimeter. Inside its white border, there are decorative designs near the bottom half. At the bottom left and bottom right of the print, the names of the artist and the engraver of this print are stated respectively. The colours on the print do not look smudged. The title of the print is stated at the bottom centre.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: This print depicts the attack by the Nemesis on Chinese war junks at Anson’s Bay on 7 January 1841. Known as the Second Battle of Chuenpee, the attack was part of the First Opium War, and contributed to the eventual cession of Hong Kong island to the British. The Nemesis, captained by Edward Belcher, was the first steam powered warship used in action by Britain. This print, based on a painting by George W. Terry, was published in Lieutenant Colonel Williams’ England’s Battles by Sea and Land by the London Printing and Publishing Company.
